# Load Station Data

msg.data:
Load Station Data

Now we load the station meta data using traditional SparkSQL DataFrame methods. Since the meta data is stored as a simple CSV, this should be simple. Nevertheless we will explicitly specify a schema, since we do not want to rely on the automatic type inference from Spark.

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.StructType
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.StructField
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.StringType
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.FloatType
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.DateType

def extractFloat = udf((v:String) => if (v != null) v.toFloat else None, FloatType)

val isdSchema = StructType(
        StructField("usaf", StringType) ::
        StructField("wban", StringType) ::
        StructField("name", StringType) ::
        StructField("country", StringType) ::
        StructField("state", StringType) ::
        StructField("icao", StringType) ::
        StructField("latitude", StringType) ::
        StructField("longitude", StringType) ::
        StructField("elevation", StringType) ::
        StructField("date_begin", DateType) ::
        StructField("date_end", DateType) ::
        Nil
    )
val isd = sqlContext.read
    .option("header","true")
    .option("dateFormat","yyyyMMdd")
    .schema(isdSchema)
    .csv("s3://dimajix-training/data/weather/isd-history")
    .withColumn("latitude", extractFloat($"latitude"))
    .withColumn("longitude", extractFloat($"longitude"))
    .withColumn("elevation", extractFloat($"elevation"))
    

z.show(isd.limit(10))
isd.printSchema()

# Spark Structured Streaming

%md
# 1. Connect to data source

First you need to run the netcat program, for example via

    spark-training/utils/pynetcat.py -I1 -B10 -P9977 < weather_sample.txt

Then we connect to the raw data socket as the datasource by using the `DataStreamReader` API via `spark.readStream`. We need to specify the options `host`, `port` and we need to use the format `socket` for connecting to the data source. The socket will stream weather data samples in raw format, i.e. one record per line.

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.IntegerType
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.FloatType

val weather = lines
    .withColumn("date", lines("value").substr(16,8))
    .withColumn("time", lines("value").substr(24,4))
    .withColumn("usaf", lines("value").substr(5,6))
    .withColumn("wban", lines("value").substr(11,5))
    .withColumn("air_temperature_quality", lines("value").substr(93,1).cast(IntegerType))
    .withColumn("air_temperature", lines("value").substr(88,5).cast(FloatType)/10.0)
    .withColumn("wind_speed_quality", lines("value").substr(70,1).cast(IntegerType))
    .withColumn("wind_speed", lines("value").substr(66,4).cast(FloatType)/10.0)

# 6. SQL Output

We also like to persist the aggregated data into a SQL Database (MySQL in this case). The database will have the following schema:

* country - String
* year - String
* temp_min - Float
* temp_axn - Float
* wind_min - Float
* wind_max - Float

Primary key is `country` and `year`. 

In order to perform this task, we will implement a `JDBCSink` for writing streaming results into a MySQL Database.
